title: Morongo Band of Mission Indians
text:
The Morongo Band of Mission Indians is a <a href="federally%20recognized%20tribe">federally recognized tribe</a> in California, United States. The main tribal groups are <a href="Cahuilla">Cahuilla</a> and <a href="Serrano%20%28people%29">Serrano</a>. Tribal members also include <a href="Cupe%C3%B1o">Cupeño</a>, <a href="Luise%C3%B1o%20people">Luiseño</a>, and <a href="Chemehuevi">Chemehuevi</a> Indians. Although many tribes in California are known as <a href="Mission%20Indians">Mission Indians</a>, some, such as those at Morongo, were never a part of the <a href="Spanish%20Missions%20in%20California">Spanish Missions in California</a>.
The Morongo Reservation is located in <a href="Riverside%20County%2C%20California">Riverside County, California</a> in the <a href="San%20Gorgonio%20Pass">San Gorgonio Pass</a>. Established as the Portrero Reservation by executive order in 1876 under President <a href="Ulysses%20S.%20Grant">Ulysses S. Grant</a>, and called Malki by the Native Americans, the "Morongo" name was adopted by 1908 when the land was <a href="Land%20patent">patented</a> to the Morongo Band of Mission Indians. The tribe has developed a large casino and hotel resort at <a href="Cabazon%2C%20California">Cabazon</a> to generate revenues for tribal welfare and economic development.
Reservation.
The Morongo Reservation () is located at the base of the <a href="San%20Gorgonio%20Mountain">San Gorgonio</a> and <a href="San%20Jacinto%20Mountains">San Jacinto Mountains</a>. It is more than in size. On May 15, 1876, President <a href="Ulysses%20S.%20Grant">Ulysses S. Grant</a> established this and eight other reservations in the area by <a href="executive%20order">executive order</a>. Approximately 954 of the 996 enrolled tribal members live on the reservation.
The name "Morongo" is derived from the Serrano <a href="clan">clan</a>, "Maarrenga". The first official "Captain" of "Potrero Ajenio" (aka "San Gorgonio Agency"), recognized by the <a href="Bureau%20of%20Indian%20Affairs">Bureau of Indian Affairs</a>, was the hereditary leader of the Maarrenga, known to Americans by his English name, John Morongo. As time went on, the Bureau began to refer to the tribe as the "Morongo Band of Mission Indians".

Education.
The reservation is served by the <a href="Banning%20Unified%20School%20District">Banning Unified School District</a>.
Languages.
<a href="Cahuilla%20language">Cahuilla</a> and <a href="Serrano%20language">Serrano</a> are <a href="Takic%20languages">Takic languages</a>, part of the <a href="Uto-Aztecan%20language%20family">Uto-Aztecan language family</a>. The main aboriginal group of the San Gorgonio Pass are Pass Cahuilla, who call the area "Maalki". The Serrano, who had traditionally intermarried with the Pass Cahuilla, and who have lived in the area since well before the inception of the reservation, call the area "Maarrkinga'."
The Cahuilla and Serrano languages are technically considered to be extinct as they are no longer spoken at home, and children are no longer learning them as primary languages. Joe Saubel, a Morongo tribal member and the last pure speaker of Pass Cahuilla, died in 2008. The last pure speaker of Serrano was an enrolled member at Morongo, Ms. Dorothy Ramon, who died in 2002. Recent generations have found a renewed interest in their native languages, however. Many families are working to have their children educated to speak Pass Cahuilla and/or Serrano.
In 2012, the Limu Project announced that it had successfully reconstructed Pass Cahuilla, and it is offering an online course. The project also offers online courses in Maarrenga' (Morongo Band "Serrano" dialect) and Yuhaviat (Santos Manuel Band "Serrano" dialect).
Programs, economic and cultural development.
Gaming.
The tribe opened a small bingo hall in 1983, which became the foundation of what is now one of the oldest Native gaming enterprises in California. The government of <a href="Riverside%20County">Riverside County, California</a>, attempted to shut down the bingo hall. The tribe joined with the <a href="Cabazon%20Band%20of%20Mission%20Indians">Cabazon Band of Mission Indians</a> in suing the local government, a case that eventually was decided by the <a href="U.S.%20Supreme%20Court">U.S. Supreme Court</a>. On February 25, 1987, the court upheld the right of sovereign Indian tribes to operate gaming enterprises on their reservations.
The <a href="Morongo%20Casino%2C%20Resort%20%26amp%3B%20Spa">Morongo Casino, Resort & Spa</a> was opened in 2004 in <a href="Cabazon%2C%20California">Cabazon, California</a>. It is open seven days a week, 24 hours a day. The hotel has 310 rooms. Several restaurants and bars are part of the complex: Desert Orchid: contemporary Asian cuisine, Potrero Canyon Buffet, Cielo: Pacific Coast Steak and Seafood Restaurant, Serrano, Sunset Bar and Grill, a food court, Mystique Lounge, and the Pit Bar. The club, 360, is open on weekends.
Water.
The tribe participated in development of a water bottling plant on the reservation. It is operated by <a href="Nestl%C3%A9%20Waters%20North%20America">Nestle Waters North America Inc.</a>, which leases the property from the tribe. The plant bottles <a href="Arrowhead%20Water">Arrowhead</a> spring water, as well as purified water sold under the brand <a href="Nestl%C3%A9%20Pure%20Life">Nestle Pure Life</a>. In his 2010 book, "Bottled and Sold: The Story Behind Our Obsession with Bottled Water," author Peter H. Gleick said the plant was producing more than 1 billion bottles of Arrowhead spring water per year.
Cultural.
The <a href="List%20of%20museums%20in%20the%20Inland%20Empire%20%28California%29">Malki Museum</a> on the Morongo Reservation is open to the public. It maintains the Malki Museum Press, which publishes the "<a href="Journal%20of%20California%20and%20Great%20Basin%20Anthropology">Journal of California and Great Basin Anthropology</a>" and scholarly books on Native American culture. The reservation is also home to the Limu Project, a tribal community-based nonprofit organization that helps families preserve knowledge of their indigenous languages, history, and cultural traditions.
Churches.
Two churches are on the Morongo Reservation. They are the Protestant <a href="Moravian%20Church%20in%20North%20America">Morongo Moravian Church</a> and the Catholic St. Mary's Mission, maintained by the <a href="Kateri%20Tekakwitha">Saint Kateri Tekakwitha</a> Catholic Community.
